reviewText: I'm here mostly - and by "mostly," I mean "exclusively" - to talk about Three Wise Women, seeing as how I haven't seen the other three films in this set. 2010's Three Wise Women may be the umpteenth reworking of Dickens' A Christmas Carol, but it's sort of a fresh take and the cast flaunts that cute Irish accent, so, yeah, I'm all in. It opens in the near future, in Dublin, year 2040. There, we note a lonely old woman named Beth (Fionnula Flanagan) whiling away her dreary solitary Christmas. The voiceover, provided by a guardian angel named Tom (Hugh O'Conor), gives us the sad lowdown on her.***Oh, I guess I should put up the plot SPOILER alert somewhere along here; I guess you ought to skip to the last paragraph if you're one of them "I don't want to know nuthin' about nuthin' viewers"***Then, in Dublin, year 1999, we eyeball young Ellie (Lauren Coe), she of the bright future and the passion for Yuletide. Don't believe me? Abide a bit and you'll soon hear her profess to her pal Bobby O'Brien: "Call me a sucker, but I just love Christmas." The universe must nurse a mean streak because moments after Ellie's happy confession, she catches her dad in an affair and when she goes scurrying to her boyfriend, she catches him locking lips with another girl. Ellie then breaks that one covenant; she vows to give up on love. And when you give up on love, you lose your guardian angel. Moments after Ellie's cry of outrage, a car slams into her.Sixteen years later, Dr. Elizabeth Kilcoyne (Amy Huberman) walks into the frame, distant and very much career-oriented. Liz (sometimes, she's called Ellen) is a leading physician in the orthopedics department. She's close to perfecting a serum to cure spinal cord maladies, and here's her fiancé (and hospital administrator) Peter (Richard Flood) seeing dollar signs (or the equivalent of Irish coin). You and I, we can tell right away that Peter isn't right for Liz, especially once she's reacquainted with her childhood pal Bobby O'Brien (Brendan Patricks) who's now an architect ramrodding a noisy project in one of the hospital wings.Because of her giving up on love sixteen years ago, Elizabeth Kilcoyne's life has gone horribly wrong, and Archangel Green (John Rhys-Davies) cannot countenance this. He suspends the angelic code to give Liz a second chance. He grants Liz's once guardian angel Tom a four-day deadline to set things right, this deadline expiring at 10pm on Christmas Eve. The caveat is that Tom cannot interact at all with Liz.Press on now to a scene or two of Tom's not getting anywhere with the oblivious Liz. Finally, frantically, he arrives at the core premise of the film. Messing about with the space/time continuum, he pulls Ellie from 1999 and Beth from 2040 and plonks them in present-day Dublin. So can Liz's past and future selves interact with her and guide her and tweak their destiny back onto its intended path? C'mon, it's a damn cute premise.Okay, Fionnula Flanagan is over-the-top, Amy Huberman is perfectly fine, and Lauren Coe is awesome. Coe, lively and so natural, is the one who kicks life into the film. In the here and now she passes herself off as Liz's suspiciously young, needs-a-filter temp secretary "Ellen Kilfeather." It should be noted that Tom pulls Ellie just after her car accident in 1999 and so she enters present-day Dublin still inflicted with amnesia. She has no recollection of her father's unfaithfulness, as evidenced by her uncomplicated, joyous expression when he walks into the office. And probably we can forgive Liz's not recognizing in Ms. Kilfeather her own face when she was younger. Other characters bring up the uncanny resemblance often enough. I love that Ellie gets so psyched about the advances in mobile phone technology ("Oh, it's a camera, too!"). And I dig the Furiousity Fox, a plush toy that gobbles up nightmares, finds them tasty. Listen, there are no real surprises in Three Wise Women. But most of the cast endear themselves to you and the story breezes along, and, hey, it's Christmastime, and Amy Huberman makes for a delectable Scroogy subject. But, honestly, for me, it's all about "Ellen Kilfeather."
summary: ...all about Ellen Kilfeather and the Furiousity Fox...

reviewText: I purchased this movie set because of the two movies Id seen in the past and come to find out the other two are just as good.Its are great set to watch as a family great clean fun for both children and adults.I love to share movies like these with my family like grandparents and aunts and even my uncles.It means alot to build these memories with the people I love most.
